facts.text: High Court resettled the first question on Rule 5

anchor.surface_text: The High Court resettled the first question we are asked to answer as follows - Whether on a true companystruction of Rule 5 of Schedule II of the Excess Profits Tax Act the expression so far as the companytrary is shown applies only to sub-clause  a  or also to sub-clause  b  ?

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court that 'so far as the contrary is shown' applies to both clauses a and b of Rule 5

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the answer given by the High Court, namely that the words so far as the companytrary is shown apply to both clauses  a  and  b .

concepts.unlisted_description: Artificial presumption created by Rule 5 that can be rebutted by showing contrary facts

anchor.surface_text: His contention is that Rule 5 is an artificial rule which creates a fiction, namely that the profits accrue evenly over the year even when that is not the fact. Therefore the moment either party shows that this is not the case Rule 5 falls to the ground as a whole because the artificial presumption it created has been rebutted.

concepts.interpretation: Rule 5 creates fictions regarding even accrual of profits and corresponding capital changes; fictions apply unless rebutted

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ground as a whole because the artificial presumption it created has been rebutted. Clause  b , he companytends, cannot have any independent existence

arguments.claim: Rule 5 creates a fiction of even accrual; rebuttal of fiction causes whole rule to fall

anchor.surface_text: His contention is that Rule 5 is an artificial rule which creates a fiction, namely that the profits accrue evenly over the year even when that is not the fact. Therefore the moment either party shows that this is not the case Rule 5 falls to the ground as a whole

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ground as a whole because the artificial presumption it created has been rebutted. Clause  b , he companytends, cannot have any independent existence

arguments.court_reasoning: Fiction created by 'deemed' applies to both clauses separately; 'except' allows rebuttal of either

arguments.claim: clause (b) is mere corollary to clause (a) with no independent existence; acceptance of (a) requires application of (b)

anchor.surface_text: Clause b , he contends, cannot have any independent existence because it is a mere corollary to clause a . In the same way, he says, if clause a is accepted, then clause b lives also, and as clause a has been accepted here clause b must also be applied without anything more.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: In the same way, he says, if clause  a  is accepted, then clause  b  lives also, and as clause  a  has been accepted here clause  b  must also be app

arguments.court_reasoning: Each clause governed independently by 'deemed' and qualifying phrase; one rebutted other stands

anchor.surface_text: We do not agree. The word deemed clearly governs both clauses, for the fiction which the Rule creates is not only that the profits shall be deemed to have accrued at an even rate throughout the period, but further that they must be deemed to have resulted,

arguments.claim: words 'except so far as the contrary is shown' govern both clauses (a) and (b)

anchor.surface_text: In the same way, the words except so far as the contrary is shown govern both clauses and it is open to either side to rebut the artificial presumptions created by that Rule by showing that either clause does not represent the true facts.

arguments.claim: presumptions under clauses (a) and (b) rebuttable independently

anchor.surface_text: Thus, it can be shown either that the profits did not accrue at an even rate throughout the period or that the profits did not actually go to increase the capital, as for example when it was taken out of the business and handed over to charities and so forth, and if only one of the two presumptions is rebutted, the other stands.

arguments.claim: 'so far as the contrary is shown' applies to both sub-clauses (a) and (b) of Rule 5

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the answer given by the High Court, namely that the words so far as the contrary is shown apply to both clauses a and b .

arguments.court_reasoning: this is a debt and not a borrowing

arguments.claim: managing agency commission is a debt under Rule 2

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax says it is a debt within the meaning of Rule 2.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ance by the other side of the money as a loan. The relationship of bo

arguments.court_reasoning: We agree with the High Court that this is a debt and not a borrowing

arguments.claim: mere inaction cannot convert debt into borrowing/loan; requires positive act of lending and acceptance

anchor.surface_text: At bottom this is a question of fact. Of course, money so, left could, by a proper agreement between the parties, be converted into a loan, but in the absence of an agreement mere inaction on the part of the managing agents cannot convert the money due to them, and not withdrawn, into a loan. A loan imports a positive act of lending coupled with an acceptance by the other side of the money as a loan.

arguments.claim: Articles of Agreement do not convert commission into loan; merely fix due date, unpaid amount remains debt

anchor.surface_text: The clause in the Articles of Agreement quoted above was relied on for the purpose of showing that there was such an agreement in the case. We are unable to construe the provisions in that way. They merely give the managing agents a right to receive their commission at a certain time. If the money is not paid in time it lies with the assessee as a debt due to the agents.

arguments.claim: managing agency commission is debt under Rule 2 not borrowing under Rule 2A

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that it is a debt under Rule 2 and not a borrowing under Rule 2A.

holdings.text: the words 'so far as the contrary is shown' apply to both clauses (a) and (b) of Rule 5 of Schedule II

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the answer given by the High Court, namely that the words so far as the contrary is shown apply to both clauses a and b .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual construction: 'deemed' governs both clauses creating fictions for accrual and capital change; qualifying phrase 'except so far as the contrary is shown' applies to both allowing independent rebuttal; agrees with High Court

holdings.text: presumptions under clauses (a) and (b) of Rule 5 are independent and rebuttable separately; rebuttal of one leaves the other intact

anchor.surface_text: Thus, it can be shown either that the profits did not accrue at an even rate throughout the period or that the profits did not actually go to increase the capital, as for example when it was taken out of the business and handed over to charities and so forth, and if only one of the two presumptions is rebutted, the other stands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Each clause has independent operation under 'deemed'; either presumption rebuttable by showing contrary facts without affecting the other

holdings.text: managing agency commission left unpaid with assessee is a debt under Rule 2 of Schedule II and not a borrowing under Rule 2A

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that this is a debt and not a borrowing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with High Court; unpaid commission due under agreement remains debt absent conversion to loan; mere leaving money does not create borrowing

holdings.text: managing agency commission payable under Articles of Agreement but left unpaid is a debt, not converted to loan or borrowing

anchor.surface_text: The clause in the Articles of Agreement quoted above was relied on for the purpose of showing that there was such an agreement in the case. We are unable to construe the provisions in that way. They merely give the managing agents a right to receive their commission at a certain time. If the money is not paid in time it lies with the assessee as a debt due to the agents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement fixes due date and payment timing; non-payment leaves amount as debt due, no provision converts to loan

holdings.text: a borrowing or loan requires positive act of lending coupled with acceptance as loan by recipient; mere inaction cannot convert due debt into loan

anchor.surface_text: At bottom this is a question of fact. Of course, money so, left could, by a proper agreement between the parties, be converted into a loan, but in the absence of an agreement mere inaction on the part of the managing agents cannot convert the money due to them, and not withdrawn, into a loan. A loan imports a positive act of lending coupled with an acceptance by the other side of the money as a loan.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes debt from loan/borrowing by requiring active steps, not passive retention of owed money

holdings.text: it is a debt under Rule 2 and not a borrowing under Rule 2A

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that it is a debt under Rule 2 and not a borrowing under Rule 2A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Final agreement with High Court on classification after factual and textual analysis

anchor.surface_text: At bottom this is a question of fact. Of course, money so, left could, by a proper agreement between the parties, be converted into a loan, but in the absence of an agreement mere inaction on the part of the managing agents cannot convert the money due to them, and not withdrawn, into a loan. A loan imports a positive act of lending coupled with an acceptance by the other side of the money as a loan.
